metadata.case_name: State of Bihar v. Rani Sonabati Kumari

facts.text: The Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950 provided for transference to the State of interests of proprietors and tenure-holders in estates, received assent of President on September 11, 1950, published in Bihar Gazette on September 25, 1950.

Rani Sonabati Kumari, proprietress of Ghatwali Estate of Handwa, instituted Title Suit 40 of 1950 against State of Bihar on November 20, 1950, for declaration that the Act was ultra vires, illegal, void, unconstitutional, and for permanent injunction restraining State from issuing notification under Act or taking possession or interfering with management.

Along with plaint, respondent filed petition for temporary injunction restraining State from issuing notification under Act and interfering with possession till disposal of suit. Court issued ex parte ad interim injunction.
State filed counter-affidavit on December 9, 1950 opposing interim injunction.

Petition heard on March 19, 1951; Subordinate Judge made ad interim injunction absolute: defendant shall not issue any notification for taking over possession under Land Reforms Act and shall not interfere with plaintiff's possession until suit disposed of.
State did not appeal order under O.43 r.1(r) CPC, order became final.
State filed application on May 17, 1952 to vacate injunction, ground: validity of Act upheld by Supreme Court.

Before hearing of vacation application (heard May 30, 1952, reserved to June 2), State issued notification on May 19, 1952 under s.3(1) Bihar Land Reforms Act declaring Handwa Raj Estate vested in State, authenticated by Additional Secretary K. Mitra.
Respondent moved Subordinate Judge on June 2, 1952 for action against State for contempt under O.39 r.2(3) CPC.
State responded that notification valid due to Art.31B Constitution.
Subordinate Judge on July 31, 1952 ordered attachment of State property to value of Rs.5,000 for breach by notification.
State appealed to Patna High Court; appeal dismissed on June 30, 1954. Certificate under Art.133(1)(c) granted.

legal_issues.text: Whether a State is liable to be proceeded against under O.39 r.2(3) CPC when it wilfully disobeys an order of temporary injunction passed against it.

petitioner_arguments.text: Order of Subordinate Judge dated March 19, 1951 did not on its plain language interdict issue of notification under s.3(1) Act, but merely directed State not to disturb possession of plaintiff.

Order reasonably capable of two interpretations: (a) prohibition against issuing notification under s.3(1); (b) no interdiction against notifications but only those interfering with possession. Bona fide conduct on one interpretation not contempt.
Rule that Crown/State cannot be proceeded against for tort or wrongdoing applies; disobedience of injunction is wrong for which O.39 r.2(3) provides punishment.
State not bound by statute unless named expressly or by necessary implication; no mention of State in O.39 r.2(3) CPC.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: Director of Rationing v. Corporation of Calcutta

petitioner_arguments.text: Publication of notification under s.3(1) not proved to be act of State Government; only Additional Secretary authenticated, so only he liable if at all.

respondent_arguments.text: Notification under s.3(1) issued by State constituted breach of injunction order.

court_reasoning.text: Order prohibited notification under s.3(1) as only relevant notification; has effect of divesting title and vesting in State. Read with plaint and petition, clearly covers s.3(1) notification.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Notification under s.3(1) breaches first part of order.

court_reasoning.text: Order not ambiguous; only one reasonable construction. State's conduct (applying to vacate before issuing, no denial of disobedience in response) shows no bona fide misconstruction.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No factual basis for bona fide misunderstanding.

court_reasoning.text: Art.300 permits suits against State; proceedings under O.39 r.2(3) are for enforcement of injunction, akin to execution under O.21 r.32 CPC, not purely quasi-criminal excluding State.
CPC scheme (ss.79-82, O.27) binds State; O.39 r.2(3) 'person guilty' includes defendant State and its agents; necessary implication binds State.
court_reasoning.key_observation: State occupies same position as other parties.

court_reasoning.text: Notification made in name of Governor, authenticated per Art.166(2); State Government responsible under s.3(1) Act, Governor responsible for subordinates' acts.

holdings.text: State is liable to be proceeded against under O.39 r.2(3) CPC for wilful disobedience of temporary injunction; notification under s.3(1) was breach.

precedents_cited.case_name: District Board of Bhagalpur v. Province of Bihar
precedents_cited.relevance: Discussed Crown liability in tort but not applicable to enforcement of injunction.
Observations on State contempt obiter; not applicable where disobedience by Government act.

precedents_cited.case_name: Director of Rationing Distribution v. Corporation of Calcutta
precedents_cited.relevance: Rule of construction for statutes binding Crown; CPC binds State by scheme.
Executive power includes decision and execution; Governor responsible for subordinates.

statutes_cited.name: Bihar Land Reforms Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Notification under s.3(1) vests estate in State, breaches injunction.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Civil Procedure, 1908
statutes_cited.relevance: Governs temporary injunctions, enforcement by attachment/detention; binds State.

statutes_cited.name: Constitution of India
statutes_cited.relevance: Suits against State; executive power vesting; authentication of orders.

outcome.summary: Appeal dismissed; High Court order upheld confirming Subordinate Judge's order attaching State property worth Rs.5,000 for contempt by issuing notification in breach of injunction.
outcome.relief_granted: Attachment of State property to value of Rs.5,000

key_quotes.text: It is of the essence of the rule of law that every authority within the State including the Executive Government should consider itself bound by and obey the Law.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Emphasizes duty of State to obey court orders.

key_quotes.text: When once an order has been passed which the Court has jurisdiction to pass, it is the duty of all persons bound by it to obey the order so long as it stands.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on obedience to interim orders.
